page.title: 03Ecology in Ormskirk
page.content: We found most of the footpaths marked on our map, but one or two had vanished and one was very overgrown and not easily walkable. A few hedges remain. Most of these are of hawthorn and planted to protect the crops. One stretch of ancient hedge contains beech, privet, sycamore and hawthorn in a 30 metre stretch. One farmer we talked to is conscious of the need to conserve plants and wild flowers and will not allow council spraying on his land. We saw daisies, buttercups, dandelions and foxgloves. Also he has planted 400 young trees, as the trees have been destroyed in the past to make more land for crops. He also keeps peacocks, ducks and free-range hens.
